INQUIRY COMMISSION'S REPORT ON MR ONG ENG GUAN'S
ALLEGATIONS
(By-election in Hong Lim)


Statement by the Minister for Home Affairs


2.31 p.m.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, Members will recall that on 29th December, 1960, you announced that at 2.13 p.m. on that day the former Member for Hong Lim, Mr Ong Eng Guan, tendered his resignation to you. It was 17 minutes before he was expected to

Column: 1058

appear before the House in Committee to substantiate his allegations as he had said he wanted to do. My colleague the Deputy Prime Minister, as Leader of the House, stated in col. 929 of Hansard, Vol. 14, No. 11:

    `This last-minute reversal of stand, after stating explicitly that he intended to substantiate charges which we believe to be false, speaks for itself. I had expected him, honour bound, to pursue the allegations he had made in this House. However, in view of the fact that he has changed his mind 17 minutes before the sitting of this Assembly, I have to move that the motion that is before the House should be adjourned sine die.

    The purpose of this adjournment sine die is that since Mr Ong Eng Guan, the man who has made the allegations, is no longer a Member of this House, it will be better to have the allegations investigated and conducted outside this Chamber. It is intended, therefore, to set up a Commission of Inquiry with a High Court Judge as Commissioner to investigate the truth of the allegations that have been made against two Ministers, It is our hope that the Commission will commence its hearing and complete its findings as soon as possible so that they could be tabled in this House. Thereupon, I shall ask for this motion to be put back on the Order Paper for debate.

    After the Inquiry Report has been tabled in this House, steps will be taken to hold a by-election in the constituency of Hong Lim.'

    In accordance with this statement, a Commission of Inquiry with a High Court Judge as Commissioner has investigated the truth of the allegations made by Mr Ong Eng Guan against two Ministers, and completed its hearings and reported its findings within six weeks. The Report has been tabled and will be debated this afternoon.

    I have to announce that a Writ for Elections to be held in the constituency of Hong Lim will be issued tomorrow, 2nd March. Nomination Day, as required by the Elections Ordinance, will be nine days after the issue of the writ, on Saturday, 11th March.

INQUIRY COMMISSION'S REPORT ON MR ONG ENG GUAN'S
ALLEGATIONS
(Motion of Condemnation)


2.37 p.m.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That this Assembly takes note of the Report of the Inquiry Commission into certain allegations made by Mr Ong Eng Guan in the Legislative Assembly on the 10th and 12th December, 1960, as contained in Paper Cmd. 7 of 1961, and condemns Mr Ong Eng Guan for his dishonourable conduct unbecoming of an elected representative of the people in that he repeatedly used his privilege in this Assembly as a cloak for spreading malicious falsehoods to unjustly injure innocent persons both inside and outside this Assembly.

Column: 1060

During the debate on the Budget Estimates in December last year, Mr Ong Eng Guan, then Member for Hong Lim, made certain allegations against the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law. Because Mr Ong Eng Guan did not substantiate those allegations, I on the 19th December, 1960, moved a motion in the following terms:-

    `That this House condemns the Member for Hong Lim for his dishonourable conduct unbecoming of an elected representative of the people in that he repeatedly used his privilege in this Assembly as a cloak for spreading malicious falsehoods to unjustly injure innocent persons both inside and outside this Assembly; that he be suspended from the service of this Assembly until such time as (i) he apologises to this Assembly for his dishonourable conduct; (ii) he unreservedly withdraws his unfounded allegations against the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law; and (iii) he assures the Assembly that he will not persist in abusing his privilege in this Assembly by uttering malicious falsehoods, unless he be prepared when challenged to repeat outside the Assembly the charges he makes in the Assembly.'

In the debate on this motion, I listed three specific allegations made by him. One allegation concerns the re-employment of Mr M. R. Marcus in the City Council. In col. 786 in Hansard, No. 9, Vol. 14, dated 19th December, 1960, Mr Ong Eng Guan said:

    `I wonder if this is the way to get away from the P.S.C. in order to give a job to this particular officer who happens to be a brother-in-law of a Minister.'

The other two allegations concern the appointment of Mr Kwa Soon Chuan as Deputy Commissioner (Valuation). In col. 786 of the same volume of Hansard of the same number, he said:

    `Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not wish to put it to the Minister that many of these recommendations - which I have read myself - are meant for the purpose of fixing up certain things.'

He also said:

    `In my opinion, there is nothing, as far as I know, to merit the transfer other than the fact that he is the brother-in-law of the Prime Minister.'

These were serious allegations as they implied that these officers had been favoured in the civil service because they happened to be related to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law.

Column: 1061



    During the debate on this motion, Mr Ong Eng Guan sought to by-pass my motion by challenging the ruling of the Speaker in admitting my motion of condemnation, and that this Assembly had no jurisdiction to deal with the matters raised therein. We, on the Government side, were in no doubt at all that the Assembly had powers to condemn the Member for Hong Lim in the circumstances of the case and in the light of the constitutional and statutory provisions extant in Singapore. The Opposition, however, sought to make political capital out of this matter by supporting Mr Ong Eng Guan. They confessed that they were confused on the admissibility of the motion. You, Mr Speaker, have since sought the opinion of the Fourth Clerk-at-the-Table in the House of Commons-a senior officer of that House primarily charged with the special duty, when asked, of assisting and advising legislatures in the Commonwealth on matters referred to him by the Clerks of such legislatures. You, Mr Speaker, read out the opinion of the Fourth Clerk-at-the-Table at the sitting of the Assembly last Wednesday. The Fourth Clerk-at-the-Table states that he would be fairly certainly of the opinion that the Assembly does have such powers. He adds [Hansard, Vol. 14, No. 13, 22nd February, 1961]:

    `There seems to be nothing indeed to prevent any deliberative body (such as for example the Council of a Trade Union) doing this, provided that the motion does not contain a libel. In the case of the Legislative Assembly, the question of libel does not arise in view of Section 3 of the Powers and Privileges Ordinance, 1955. Furthermore the words "except upon a substantive motion moved for that purpose" contained in Standing Order 46 (10) would appear expressly to envisage the moving of a motion condemning a Member for his personal conduct.'

In brief, the Fourth Clerk-at-the-table admits that this Assembly, on a substantive motion, has the power to condemn Mr Ong Eng Guan for dishonourable conduct.

    On the 23rd December, 1960, Mr Ong Eng Guan said he wished to substantiate all the things he had said; he had nothing to apologise for. But, however, he pleaded for time to prepare his case.

Column: 1062

The Government had no intention to prevent him from speaking or to prevent him from seeking advice elsewhere. The debate was, therefore, accordingly adjourned to the 29th December, 1960, when the House would resolve itself into Committee to hear whatever evidence he could bring forward to substantiate those allegations.

    On the 29th December, 1960, Members assembled in this Chamber - the Opposition perhaps agog with excitement, thinking that Mr Ong Eng Guan would provide them with the cudgels to hammer at the P.A.P. December 29th, however, turned out to be an anti-climax instead. On that day you, Mr Speaker, announced that Mr Ong Eng Guan had tendered his resignation from the Assembly a few minutes earlier. Although Mr Ong Eng Guan sought to run away from giving evidence in Committee of the Assembly, the Government obviously could not allow the matter to rest there. If we had permitted Mr Ong Eng Guan to leave his allegations unsubstantiated in the Assembly, the smears that he had uttered would have stuck and grave injustice would have been done to the persons against whom he had made these allegations. Accordingly I moved that the motion condemning Mr Ong Eng Guan be adjourned sine die, and announced that the Government would set up a Commission of Inquiry with a High Court Judge as Commissioner to investigate the truth of the allegations that have been made against the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law.

    A commission under Mr Justice Chua was appointed on the 31st December, 1960, with these terms of reference:

    `(a) to inquire into the truth of the allegations on the re-appointment of Mr M. R. Marcus in the City Council made by Mr Ong Eng Guan in the Legislative Assembly on the 10th December, 1960;

    (b) to inquire into the truth of the allegations on the appointment of the Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) made by Mr Ong Eng Guan in the Legislative Assembly on the 12th December,1960;

Column: 1063



    (c) to inquire into the truth of the allegations on the appointment of Mr Kwa Soon Chuan as Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) made by Mr Ong Eng Guan in the Legislative Assembly on the 12th December, 1960.'

During the Inquiry an undertaking was given by the State Advocate-General on behalf of the Government that:

    `No action under the Official Secrets Ordinance or under any other written law and no disciplinary action will be taken by the Government against any person who prior to this Inquiry disclosed any information on any matter relating to or in respect of this Inquiry and/or who will be giving evidence in this Inquiry'.

We gave this undertaking because we had nothing evil to hide and we were anxious that the truth be out. Members have by now studied the Report of the Commission of Inquiry and read the findings of the Commission. On Mr Ong Eng Guan's evidence in chief the Commissioner had this to say: (On page 6, paragraphs 14 and 15 of the Report of the Inquiry Commission, Paper Cmd. 7 of 1961).

    `14. Mr Ong Eng Guan gave me the impression that he was in possession of some inside knowledge about the Government and I anticipated that startling disclosures would be made. I gathered this impression because the first two days' hearing and part of the third day's hearing were taken up by arguments by his counsel that Government should give an undertaking in no uncertain terms that witnesses who gave evidence before the Commission would not be liable to criminal proceedings or disciplinary actions and such an undertaking was given by the Government. Mr Ong Eng Guan, however, had nothing to disclose. He did not even have any facts on which he based his allegations.

    15. Mr Ong Eng Guan, in the course of giving his evidence, made statements which were either half-truths or vague allegations with the intention of misleading the Commission. I find that he would tell an untruth when it suited him. All the three allegations made by Mr Ong Eng Guan in the Legislative Assembly against the Prime Minister and the Minister for Labour and Law and all the allegations which he made against the Prime Minister in the course of giving his evidence in this Commission are untrue, groundless and reckless. Mr Ong Eng Guan is a person not to be believed.'

    On the re-employment of Mr M. R. Marcus into the City Council, Mr P. C. Lim, who was described by Mr Ong

Column: 1064

Eng Guan as his key witness, told the Commission that there was nothing improper about the re-employment of Mr M. R. Marcus, and the Commissioner found that Mr K. M. Byrne did not influence the Prime Minister to re-employ Mr M. R. Marcus and he had nothing to do with Mr M. R. Marcus' re-employment. The Commissioner was satisfied that the Prime Minister in re-employing Mr M. R. Marcus did so in accordance with certain principles which he laid down, when he took over control of the City Council from Mr Ong Eng Guan, for the re-employment of City Council Officers who had resigned during the period when Mr Ong Eng Guan was in charge of the City Council. The Prime Minister showed no bias towards Mr M. R. Marcus. The Commissioner found that there was nothing improper in re-employing Mr M. R. Marcus and the allegation of Mr Ong Eng Guan is untrue and groundless.

    On the establishment of the post of Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) and the appointment of Mr Kwa Soon Chuan to this post the Commissioner said (in paras. 26 and 29 in page 9, and in paras. 39, 40, 41 and 42 in page 12 of the Report of the Inquiry Commission, Paper Cmd. 7 of 1961):

    `26. Mr Ong Eng Guan's allegations are that these members of the Working Party were all under the instructions of the Prime Minister or the Minister for Finance, and that "it would be in the interest of civil servants for their own personal good and welfare to take directions without question from their Ministers", and that they set out to make recommendations for the creation of the post of Deputy Commissioner (Valuation), and that subsequently they drew up qualifications for that post to tailor the job for Mr Kwa Soon Chuan, a brother-in-law of the Prime Minister, so that the Prime Minister could place his brother-in-law in a key position.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan said that he felt that the Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) had far wider statutory powers than the Deputy Commissioner of Lands. This was said to show to the Commission that the post of Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) was a key post. When Mr Ong Eng Guan was questioned he was unable to substantiate it. This statement of Mr Ong Eng Guan is absolute nonsense.'

Column: 1065



    `29. I find that no Minister interferred in any way with the work and deliberations of the Working Party and that when it came to a definite recommendation that recommendation was put to the Minister for Finance for his decision. I find that there is no truth in the allegation of Mr Ong Eng Guan that the post of Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) was created just for Mr Kwa Soon Chuan.'

    `39. In the course of his evidence Mr Ong Eng Guan mentioned the names of Mr Lim Eng Bee, the Chairman of the Public Service Commission, Mr Lim Kim San, the Deputy Chairman, and Dr Phay Seng Whatt, a member of the Public Service Commission, and said that they were close friends of either the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, or the Minister for Finance. The suggestion of Mr Ong Eng Guan, it seems to me, is that any of these Ministers could easily have influenced the Public Service Commission to select Mr Kwa Soon Chuan.'

    `40. Mr Lim Eng Bee, Mr Lim Kim San, and Dr Phay Seng Whatt stated emphatically that in the course of their duties no Minister had tried to influence them and no Minister had spoken to any of them about Mr Kwa Soon Chuan. It is worthy of note that all these three gentlemen were members of the Public Service Commission when that Commission considered the promotions of timescale officers to Superscale Grade G and the Commission promoted Mr Un Hon Kun and not Mr Kwa Soon Chuan, who was then senior to Mr Un Hon Kun in the Land Office.'

    `41. The Public Service Commission had given its reasons for selecting Mr Kwa Soon Chuan and in my opinion the Public Service Commission had made a proper selection.'

    `42. I find that the posting of Mr Kwa Soon Chuan to act as Deputy Commissioner (Valuation) was done by the Establishment Branch not on the directions of the Prime Minister or any Minister but on its own initiative and on Establishment principles. I also find that no Minister had influenced the Public Service Commission in its selection of Mr Kwa Soon Chuan to be the Deputy Commissioner (Valuation). If the Prime Minister had wanted to help Mr Kwa Soon Chuan in his career in the Administrative Service he could easily have done so in February, 1960, by upholding the security objection against Mr Un Hon Kun thereby giving Mr Kwa Soon Chuan a chance of being selected for promotion or to continue to act in the post of Deputy Commissioner for Lands with the prospect of being ultimately confirmed in it.'

    Finally, as a conclusion to his findings on the terms of reference, the Commissioner had this to say (para. 43 in page 12):

Column: 1066



    `43. I find that there is no truth at all in any of the three allegations made by Mr Ong Eng Guan. These allegations are groundless and recklessly made and there is no justification for making any of them.'

    Mr Speaker, it was perhaps fortunate that Mr Ong Eng Guan left the Assembly to face an independent High Court Judge in the Commission of Inquiry, otherwise he might have gone out and said that he was intimidated by the Government majority and that judgment was passed on him by those whom he had fought. We now know that Mr Ong Eng Guan, in the Commissioner's own words, is "a person not to be believed", and who "would tell an untruth when it suited him".

    This Report of the Inquiry Commission has proved conclusively that Mr Ong Eng Guan, when he was a Member of the Assembly, had grossly abused his privilege in this Assembly in making allegations which could not be substantiated.

    Mr Speaker, let me cite a case where an abuse of Assembly privilege was made in the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly in India. A digest of what occurred in the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly has been published in the Journal of the Society of Clerks-at-the-Table in Commonwealth Parliaments, Volume XXVII for 1958, pages 128 to130.

'India: Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly


    Insinuations by a Member. - On 10th February Shri Genda Singh, M.L.A. [i.e., Member of the Legislative Assembly] gave notice of certain short notice questions.

    After scrutiny by the office about their admissibility the orders of the Deputy Speaker were obtained on 17th February, 1958, and they were tabled for answer on 21st February, 1958. Shri Genda Singh's complaint was that his questions after admission had been sent to the Minister on 11th February and that the Minister intentionally delayed giving the reply of the said questions till the 21st February. When the questions were answered on 21st February, Shri Genda Singh said that the Minister defied the Rule and deliberately delayed answering of questions. He was told by the Speaker that there had been no delay on the part of the Minister, that the question of admissibility itself had been decided up to 17th February by the Deputy Speaker and that they were tabled for answers on 21st February, which was the day meant for the Minister. Shri Genda

Column: 1067

Singh, however, insisted that his questions were admitted on 11th and had been sent to the Minister concerned for answers on the 11th and that the Minister, who was in the habit of delaying answers, intentionally delayed giving answers till the 21st and that the answers given were evasive. He persisted in his allegation that the Revenue Minister intentionally delayed the replies to the questions and was guilty of violation of rules.

    He added a request that the matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges, where many things would come to light (the implication being that there had been some tampering with the records). The Speaker thereupon referred the matter to the Privilege Committee for inquiry and report under Rule 67.

    The Committee investigated the case and in their Report came to a unanimous decision that the questions had been sent to the Revenue Minister on 17th February and that there had been no manipulation whatsoever of any kind in the records of the Assembly Secretariat. The Committee was further of the opinion that if a member deliberately makes a wrong statement and tries to mislead the House, he should be held to be guilty of the breach of privilege of the House. The Committee, therefore, came to the conclusion that the conduct of Shri Genda Singh in the House, in persisting in his charge against the Revenue Minister of his deliberately delaying the reply to his questions and his obvious insinuations that there was some tampering of records in the Assembly Secretariat, was contumacious and disrespectful and that he was thus guilty of a breach of privilege of the House.'

    Shri Genda Singh did not tender any apology for his contempt against the Revenue Minister, Shri Charan Singh, and was condemned by the Speaker.

    Now what Shri Genda Singh said in the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Assembly was pretty mild. What he had done was that he had uttered an innuendo when by saying that certain things would come to light he insinuated that there was a tampering of records and that this could be revealed by the Committee of Privileges. Mr Ong Eng Guan had uttered more than Mr Shri Genda Singh had uttered. He had made specific and direct allegations and these allegations have now been discovered by the Commission of Inquiry to be false.

    Although Mr Ong Eng Guan is not today in this Chamber, his absence, however, does not prevent the House from condemning him for his dishonourable conduct in abusing his privilege in this Assembly as a cloak for spreading

Column: 1068

malicious falsehoods to unjustly injure innocent persons both inside and outside this Assembly.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

3.13 p.m.

    Mr S. V. Lingam (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I oppose the motion of the Deputy Prime Minister. On the 11th of January, 1961, the Deputy Prime Minister said this of Mr Ong Eng Guan - I refer to Hansard [unrevised transcript], col. 984:

    `Whether a man who is prepared to be as unscrupulous as to tell lies in this Chamber should be considered worthy of representing a section of the people of Singapore - that is the main issue.'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, my colleague, Mr Ong Eng Guan, will stand as a candidate in the by-election in Hong Lim. I think it is too early to make any pronouncements on him yet. Let the people of Hong Lim decide as to who tell lies and who should be condemned.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I reject and disagree with the findings of this Commission of Inquiry. The most apt description of this Report is to use the same words spoken by the Secretary-General of the P.A.P. when he attacked the Buttrose Report on the Chew Swee Kee Inquiry published during the last general elections. Mr Speaker, Sir, I refer to the Straits Times dated 28th May, 1959, page 7, column 8:

    `The Buttrose Commission Report was criticised by leaders of the P.A.P. at a lunchtime rally at Fullerton Square.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew, Secretary-General of the Party, accused the Commissioner, Mr Justice Buttrose, of having exceeded the terms of reference. Mr Lee said, "It was not within his terms of reference to pass judgment on what I said in the Assembly. That is for the people of Singapore to decide." He said that during the Inquiry while he was cross-examining and giving evidence, Mr Justice Buttrose had been very careful to keep him (Mr Lee) within the terms of reference but he himself had strayed outside his terms of reference in several parts of the Report. Mr Lee said, "The final judgment on this matter, however, is not made by the Judge but by the next Assembly which shall debate the issue."'

Mr Speaker, Sir, the final judgment on this Report will be made by the people of Hong Lim.

Column: 1069



    Sir, may I recall a joint Press statement which my colleague, the Member for Punggol, and myself released on 30th December, 1960, wherein we said:

    `Governments like Commissions of Inquiry.

    We have not forgotten those appointed by the former Government.'

Yes, Mr Speaker, Sir, the people of Singapore have not forgotten the Commission of Inquiry into the Tanjong Pagar by-election and the Chew Swee Kee Commission of Inquiry. Neither have they forgotten the Commission of Inquiry into the City Council. Therefore, Sir, this Commission is no exception and neither will its findings - with which I disagree - change the fortunes of this Government in the Hong Lim by-election. As Commissions have failed miserably to save the S.P.A. Government, so this Commission of Inquiry will similarly fail in the Hong Lim by-election.

3.17 p.m.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I first express my condolences to the hon. Members opposite in what must be another gloomy moment in their chequered political careers?

    Sir, this is not the first time they have been embarrassed by the findings of an Inquiry Commission. Yet once again, the P.A.P. has appeared before an Inquiry Commission and vindicated its reputation for honesty and integrity. It is again the anti-P.A.P. elements who have been embarrassed by the findings of an Inquiry Commission.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan, egged on by Right-wing politicians, sought to slander the P.A.P. Government with allegations of political corruption against two Ministers. Sir, the findings of the Chua Inquiry Commission have not only cleared the two Ministers of nepotism, but have instead substantiated the P.A.P.'s contention that Mr Ong Eng Guan - who we have been

Column: 1070

told by the Member for Cairnhill would be fighting the Opposition's battle in the Hong Lim by-election - is a man not to be believed and a man who would not hesitate to tell an untruth when it suited him. This, Sir, is the opinion of an experienced Judge one of whose jobs is to assess the credibility or otherwise of a witness.

    The Member for Aljunied just now quoted the P.A.P.'s verdict on the Buttrose Commission's Report, but he did not dare, and I am quite sure he will not dare, do what the P.A.P. did. The P.A.P. made the statement about the Buttrose Commission at a public meeting and I invite the Member for Aljunied or Mr Ong Eng Guan to make the same statement about the Chua Inquiry Commission outside the Assembly at a public meeting.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the time has come when there should not be challenges of that nature shouted across the Chamber of this Assembly, because challenges of that nature may be construed as breaches of privilege of this Assembly.

    Mr Rajah: Keep to the subject.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Yes, we will keep to the subject. Mr Ong Eng Guan, who is now going to fight the Hong Lim by-election for the Opposition, has been said by Justice Chua as a man who cannot be relied upon to tell the truth or who would not hesitate to tell an untruth when it suited him. This assessment of Mr Ong was based on his performance before the Inquiry Commission in the course of only ten sittings. Mr Ong, moreover, gave his evidence under oath. Not only did Mr Ong persist in the falsehoods he uttered in this Assembly, but with pathological consistency he embarked upon fresh falsehoods during the Inquiry itself.
